lead_paragraph: Now comes crunch time for the Academy Awards. The nominations were announced on Feb. 13, and everybody has had a chance to digest them, rate the competition and build a strategy. Over the next week the official ballots will go out to the 5,600 members of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences. If common wisdom holds true, the bulk of them will be filled out and returned to the academy within 10 days. So if filmmakers want to maneuver or make their case, either on behalf of their own films or to discredit a competitor, they will need to do it quickly. DreamWorks is building an energetic campaign for the Ridley Scott epic ''Gladiator,'' which received a dozen nominations, the most for any film this year. This week the studio, whose ''American Beauty'' dominated the Oscars last year, announced a rerelease of ''Gladiator'' in some crucial Los Angeles theaters.
abstract: At the Movies column on promotions of films nominated for Oscars; Ennio Morricone, who composed score for Malena, comments on his nomination; photo (M)
